plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A deciduous tree known for its large, tulip-shaped flowers. It blooms early in spring before the leaves appear, creating a spectacular floral display in many temperate gardens.
plants.location: Temperate regions of North America, Europe, and Asia
plants.funFact: The saucer magnolia was one of the first magnolias to be hybridized and is popular for its early blooms signaling spring's arrival.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: An evergreen shrub native to the Mediterranean and parts of Asia, oleander produces clusters of fragrant, funnel-shaped flowers. It thrives in warm climates and blooms over an extended period from spring through fall.
plants.location: Mediterranean Basin, Southern United States, and subtropical regions
plants.funFact: Despite its beauty, all parts of the oleander plant are highly toxic if ingested.

plants.name: Erythronium americanum
plants.description: A wildflower native to eastern North American forests, it emerges in early spring with nodding yellow flowers and mottled leaves reminiscent of trout patterns, often forming colonies on forest floors.
plants.funFact: The mottled leaves resemble the markings of a brook trout, hence the common name.

plants.name: Jacaranda mimosifolia
plants.description: A subtropical tree famous for its striking display of purple-blue trumpet-shaped flowers that cover the tree in spring. In southern hemisphere countries, it blooms around this time, providing vibrant color to urban landscapes.
plants.location: Native to South America; cultivated in Australia, South Africa, and southern U.S. states
plants.funFact: The jacaranda tree is often called the 'Tree of Fame' due to its spectacular, showy flowers.
